information:
Reports from sources including The Boston Globe and The New York Times indicate Senator Fetterman has become increasingly isolated from the Democratic caucus. He has stopped attending the weekly Democratic lunches and has left the party's group chat. Concurrently, Republican colleagues have made deliberate outreach efforts. Newsweek reported that GOP Senators Tom Cotton, Chuck Grassley, and Dave McCormick have contacted Fetterman's office, and Republican Whip John Barrasso has publicly welcomed him to switch parties.

Concerns have been raised regarding Senator Fetterman's performance and health. As of late May 2025, he had missed approximately 30 floor votes, giving him one of the lowest attendance records in the Senate. A report from Yahoo cited a 1,600-word email from Fetterman's former chief of staff, Adam Jentleson, sent to the senator's doctor in May 2024. The email detailed 'warning signs' such as reckless driving and conspiratorial thinking. Other Democratic senators have also privately expressed worries about his ability to handle the stresses of the office.

Senator Fetterman's office has experienced significant staff turnover, with reports from The Jewish Voice and Fox News indicating that at least seven staffers have resigned. These departures include high-level aides such as his Communications Director and Legislative Director. Several of these resignations have been linked to policy disagreements, particularly Fetterman's staunch pro-Israel stance, which former staffers described as consuming the office's work environment and being 'less nuanced' than their own views.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — Fetterman continues caucusing with the Senate Democrats through June 30, 2025.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: He remains a Democrat, keeps current committee alignments, skips some caucus functions, and issues no formal switch or resignation.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: He publicly announces he is switching to Independent or Republican and no longer caucuses with Democrats, or he resigns prior to July 1, which would end his caucusing by definition.
forecast.rationale:
Baseline favors inertia over a ~1-month horizon. Party switches and mid-term resignations are rare; base rates for a single senator to switch or resign in any given month are very low. While the current friction elevates risk relative to baseline, the short timeline keeps the absolute probability modest.

Evidence raising risk: credible reporting that Fetterman is isolated from the Democratic caucus (skipping weekly lunches, leaving a caucus group chat), significant staff turnover, missed votes, and outreach from Republicans, including public encouragement to switch. These signals suggest strained relationships and make a switch or resignation more thinkable than for a typical senator.

Countervailing considerations (why not higher):
- Public stance: Fetterman has said he will not resign. Reversals happen, but stated intent matters over a 32-day window.
- Incentives: If he resigned, Pennsylvania’s Democratic governor would appoint a Democrat, so there is little partisan incentive for Republicans to push for resignation, and no reason for Fetterman to prefer that outcome now. If he switched caucuses, he would face severe political backlash in Pennsylvania, complicating his long-term position. Historically, senators switching away from their party in states like PA face daunting reelection prospects.
- Process and timing: A caucus switch typically comes with advance reporting about negotiations (committee assignments, staff transitions). We lack concrete indications of imminent procedural steps.

Why not lower: The accumulation of smoke—estrangement from Democratic colleagues, staff churn tied to policy disagreements, questions about performance/health, and active GOP courting—does lift the hazard above a background near-zero probability.

What would move me up: reliable reporting of formal talks with GOP leadership about committee assignments; changes to his party registration or Senate website affiliation; leadership statements hinting at a break; a scheduled press conference on party affiliation; acute health or personal developments prompting sudden resignation.

What would move me down: renewed participation in Democratic caucus activities; joint statements with Democratic leaders reaffirming alignment; stabilization of staffing and attendance; news cycles shifting away without further escalation.

Net: Given the short fuse to July 1 and strong status-quo pull, I put modest but non-trivial odds on a switch or resignation, with the No outcome still clearly favored.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will Senator John Fetterman cease caucusing with the Democrats before July 1, 2025?

Question background:
[Fetterman says he won’t resign, gets support from McCormick as article blowback continues](https://www.pennlive.com/news/2025/05/fetterman-says-he-wont-resign-gets-support-from-mccormick-as-article-blowback-continues.html) | [An isolated, angry Fetterman is yet another challenge for Democrats](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/16/john-fetterman-senate-relationships/)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if, before July 1, 2025, John Fetterman ceases caucusing with the [Senate Democrats](https://www.democrats.senate.gov/about-senate-dems/our-caucus) for any reason, whether because he switches parties, resigns, or any other reason.




Your research assistant's report says:
Reports from sources including The Boston Globe and The New York Times indicate Senator Fetterman has become increasingly isolated from the Democratic caucus. He has stopped attending the weekly Democratic lunches and has left the party's group chat. Concurrently, Republican colleagues have made deliberate outreach efforts. Newsweek reported that GOP Senators Tom Cotton, Chuck Grassley, and Dave McCormick have contacted Fetterman's office, and Republican Whip John Barrasso has publicly welcomed him to switch parties.

Concerns have been raised regarding Senator Fetterman's performance and health. As of late May 2025, he had missed approximately 30 floor votes, giving him one of the lowest attendance records in the Senate. A report from Yahoo cited a 1,600-word email from Fetterman's former chief of staff, Adam Jentleson, sent to the senator's doctor in May 2024. The email detailed 'warning signs' such as reckless driving and conspiratorial thinking. Other Democratic senators have also privately expressed worries about his ability to handle the stresses of the office.

Senator Fetterman's office has experienced significant staff turnover, with reports from The Jewish Voice and Fox News indicating that at least seven staffers have resigned. These departures include high-level aides such as his Communications Director and Legislative Director. Several of these resignations have been linked to policy disagreements, particularly Fetterman's staunch pro-Israel stance, which former staffers described as consuming the office's work environment and being 'less nuanced' than their own views.

Today is 2025-05-29.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
